title: Lesson 03: Linear Transformations and Matrices
objectives: Understand what makes a transformation linear

cards.front: What are the two key properties of a linear transformation?
cards.back:
1. All lines remain lines (no curves)
2. The origin remains fixed

Equivalently: grid lines remain parallel and evenly spaced.

cards.front: What two algebraic properties must a linear transformation \( L \) satisfy?
cards.back:
1. Additivity: \( L(\vec{v} + \vec{w}) = L(\vec{v}) + L(\vec{w}) \)
2. Scaling: \( L(c\vec{v}) = cL(\vec{v}) \)

These can be combined: \( L(a\vec{v} + b\vec{w}) = aL(\vec{v}) + bL(\vec{w}) \)

cards.front: How is a 2D linear transformation completely determined?
cards.back:
By tracking where the two basis vectors \( \hat{i} \) and \( \hat{j} \) land.

Once you know where \( \hat{i} \) and \( \hat{j} \) go, you know where every vector goes (since every vector is a linear combination of \( \hat{i} \) and \( \hat{j} \)).

cards.front: How do the columns of a 2x2 matrix relate to a linear transformation?
cards.back:
The first column is where \( \hat{i} \) lands.
The second column is where \( \hat{j} \) lands.

\( \begin{bmatrix} a & b \\ c & d \end{bmatrix} \) means \( \hat{i} \to [a,c] \) and \( \hat{j} \to [b,d] \)

cards.front:
How do you compute the matrix-vector product?

\( \begin{bmatrix} a & b \\ c & d \end{bmatrix} \begin{bmatrix} x \\ y \end{bmatrix} \)
cards.back:
\( x \cdot (\text{first column}) + y \cdot (\text{second column}) \)

\( = x \cdot [a,c] + y \cdot [b,d] \)
\( = [ax + by, cx + dy] \)

cards.front: What is the matrix for a 90Â° counterclockwise rotation?

cards.back:
A transformation that keeps one basis vector fixed while tilting the other.

Example (horizontal shear):
\( \begin{bmatrix} 1 & 1 \\ 0 & 1 \end{bmatrix} \) keeps \( \hat{i} \) fixed, moves \( \hat{j} \) to \( [1,1] \)
